sentences.sentence: Mr. Darcy and his sister came to visit on the same morning that Darcy’s sister, Georgina, arrived.
Elizabeth’s feelings( 感受 ) of nervousness were increasing with every moment.
She drew back from the window as they approached, afraid of being seen.
As she walked back and forth( 来来回回地 ) across the room, trying to calm herself, the looks of curious surprise from her uncle and aunt only made everything worse.
Miss Darcy and her brother entered, and introductions were made.
Elizabeth was astonished( 震惊的 ) to find that Miss Darcy was at least as much embarrassed( 尴尬的 ) as she was herself.
She had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly( 极其地 ) proud like her brother, but after observing her for a few minutes, Elizabeth was convinced( 被说服 ) that she was only exceedingly( 极其地 ) shy.
She found it difficult to get a response from her longer than a single word.
Miss Darcy was taller and larger than Elizabeth.
Though she was only a little older than sixteen, her figure was mature( 成熟的 ), and her appearance womanly and graceful( 优雅的 ).
Her manners were perfectly modest and gentle.
Elizabeth, who had assumed( 假使 ) Miss Darcy would be as severe( 苛刻的 ) and imposing( 盛气凌人的 ) as her brother, was very relieved to find her much different from what she had expected.
They had not been together for long before Mr. Darcy told Elizabeth that Bingley was also coming to visit her.
She did not even have time to fully express her satisfaction before she heard Bingley’s quick steps on the stairs( 楼梯 ), and in a moment he entered the room.
Any anger which Elizabeth had felt against him was long past, but if she had still felt any, it could not have lasted long against his cheerful sincerity( 真诚 ).
He asked in a friendly way about her family, and looked and spoke with the same happy ease as he always had before.
Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do.
Upon seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally were on her sister, because she fiercely longed to know whether he still thought of Jane.
She soon received satisfaction on this point.
He expressed to her, in a tone( 语气 ) which sounded truly regretful, that it “was a very long time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her.”
Before she could reply, he added, “We have not met since the 26th of November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
Elizabeth was pleased that his memory( 记忆 ) was so exact, and in a moment when she and Bingley were alone, he took the opportunity to ask whether all her sisters were at Longbourn.
The question was simple enough, but it was very clear to her which of her sisters he was particularly interested in.
She did not often look at Darcy, but whenever she did, he seemed so friendly and agreeable that she decided his improvement in manners,
however temporary( 暂时的 ) it might be, had at least lasted more than one day.
Their visitors stayed with them for more than half an hour, and when they stood up to leave, Mr. Darcy said he hoped to see them all together for dinner at Pemberley before they left Lambton.
Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, but Elizabeth had turned away her head.
Mrs. Gardiner assumed( 认为 ) that this was the result of a momentary embarrassment( 害羞 ) rather than any dislike of the suggestion, and the plans were made for the day after next.
As for Elizabeth, she thought of Pemberley more that evening than the last.
She lay awake for two whole hours trying to decide what her feelings( 感受 ) were about its owner.
She certainly did not hate him.
She felt thankful, not only because he had once loved her, but also because he loved her still well enough to forgive the way she had rejected him.
She respected, she esteemed( 尊敬 ), and she was grateful to him, and she felt a real interest in his well-being.
To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner it was obvious that Elizabeth was much better acquainted( 熟悉的 ) with Mr. Darcy than they had ever suspected( 怀疑 ): it was obvious that he was very much in love with her.
Curious as they were, however, they could not force her to talk, and saw nothing to justify any inquiry( 疑问 ).
Elizabeth had been disappointed not to find a letter from Jane when they had first arrived at Lambton.
But on the third morning her wait was over, and the situation made clear, when Elizabeth received two letters from her at once.
It was marked on one that it had been accidentally sent to the wrong address.
The beginning of the first letter talked about all their little parties and arrangements, and gave news from around the neighborhood.
But a second section, which was dated a day later, and written with a shakier( 更抖的 ) hand, gave more important information.
This is what it said:
“Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something very serious and unexpected has occurred.
What I have to tell is about poor Lydia.
An express letter came at twelve last night, just as we had all gone to bed.
It was from Colonel Forster, informing us that Lydia had gone off to Scotland with one of his officers.
To tell you the truth, it was with Wickham!
You can imagine our surprise.
It is such an unwise marriage on both sides!
At least we know that he is not after her money, because he must know that she has none.
I am afraid you will not be able to understand me, because I hardly even know what I have written.”
On finishing this letter, Elizabeth instantly seized the other, opening it with great impatience( 迫不及待 ).
It read as follows:
“Dearest Lizzy, I hardly know what I should write, but I have bad news for you, and I cannot delay telling you.
As disgraceful( 不光彩的 ) as a marriage between Mr. Wickham and our poor Lydia would be, we are now hopeful to hear that it has taken place.
There is now reason to fear that they have not gone to Scotland.
One of the officers said that he believed that Wickham had never intended( 打算 ) to go there, or to marry Lydia at all.
This was repeated to Colonel Forster, who instantly set off to follow and find them.
My father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly, to try to help find her.
In such an emergency, my uncle’s advice and assistance( 帮助 ) would mean so much to us all.
He will immediately understand how I must feel, and we are in great need of his help.”
“Oh! Where is my uncle?” cried Elizabeth, jumping from her seat as soon as she finished the letter.
She set off in a rush to follow him, without losing a moment of precious( 宝贵的 ) time.
Just as she had reached the door, it was opened by a servant, and Mr. Darcy appeared.
Her pale face and rushed manner made him jump with surprise.
Before he could recover enough to speak, Elizabeth hurriedly exclaimed( 说 ), “Please excuse me, but I must leave you.
I must find Mr. Gardiner this instant, on business that cannot be delayed.
I do not have a moment to lose.”
“Good God! What is the matter?” he cried, with more emotion( 情感 ) than politeness.
Then recovering a bit, he said, “I will not keep you for even a minute, but let the servant go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner.
You are not well enough to go yourself.”
Elizabeth hesitated( 犹豫 ), but her knees trembled( 颤抖 ) under her.
Calling back the servant, therefore, she ordered him to bring Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner home instantly.
